clean_story:
"Alien air. Light’s hidden stories. "

"Exoplanet atmospheres" means the layers of gas around planets outside our solar system.

When a distant planet passes in front of its star, starlight filters through its atmosphere. Like sunlight through a stained-glass window, this light carries chemical fingerprints—oxygen, methane, or even water vapor.
Telescopes like James Webb split this light into colors, revealing which gases are present. On WASP-39b, Webb detected carbon dioxide in 2022—the first clear proof of CO₂ on a planet 700 light-years away.
Some atmospheres vanish. GJ 1214 b, a "waterworld," might have a steamy, crushed atmosphere from its star’s heat. Others puff up like cotton candy—WASP-107b’s atmosphere is so light, it’s escaping into space.
These gases hint at unseen worlds: scorched deserts, global oceans, or skies raining molten glass.


Three related subjects are planet migration, biosignature gases, and rogue planet weather.
